issue.title: LoadBalancer Service takes > 1 minute to respond in libvirt NAT-networked K8S cluster when called from host
issue.body:
**Describe the bug** I have Kubernetes v1.25.4 running inside libvirt, deployed through `kubeadm`. I have kube-vip configured for both load balancing the API and `Service` `type: LoadBalancer` through ARP. The K8S API works great from my host machine and I have no issue there; however, when I deploy nginx and a `LoadBalancer` service, it takes upwards of 60 seconds for `curl` to come back. I can ping the IP and `arping` comes back with the expected VM mac address. If I `curl` the VIP address from the system it's locally bound to, it still takes about 2 seconds to come back. **To Reproduce** This is the playbook I'm building, which includes all the steps I'm taking to get in this state: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab Manual version of steps: 1. Make a NAT libvirt network with DHCP enabled on a portion of the selected subnet. 2. Bring up VMs on that network (3 control-planes, 3 workers preferably), copy over [this](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml) static pod definition to the control-plane nodes, then initialize the cluster 3. Install flannel with all the defaults 4. [Apply](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/main/roles/kubeadm/tasks/main.yml#L100-L106) the kube-vip-cloud-controller and give it a pool of non-DHCP addresses in that same subnet to use. 5. Deploy an [nginx](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/examples/nginx.yaml) `Deployment` and `Service` 6. Get the LB IP from Kubernetes (in my case, `192.168.123.10`) and curl it on port 8080. ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10:8080 Welcome to nginx!

Welcome to nginx!

If you see this page, the nginx web server is successfully installed and working. Further configuration is required.

For online documentation and support please refer to nginx.org.
Commercial support is available at nginx.com.

Thank you for using nginx.

curl 192.168.123.10:8080 0.00s user 0.00s system 0% cpu 1:04.85 total ``` Real time for the curl to come back is about 1m5s. If I try on a different port (80) which has no service bound on that port, it returns an error instantly: ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10 curl: (7) Failed to connect to 192.168.123.10 port 80 after 0 ms: Couldn't connect to server curl 192.168.123.10 0.00s user 0.00s system 92% cpu 0.005 total ``` **Expected behavior** Data would be returned within a second on a local VM based K8S cluster when curling from the host , and < 2 seconds when curling from the VM which owns the VIP. **Screenshots** Here's a packet capture from the host on the `virbr` network. This is from when I was testing on port 80. The SYN is sent and retransmitted until a minute later we get a SYN ACK from the VIP: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1342149/204119969-ed891414-8dcb-497a-8cbe-1e89a5b8d6a8.png) **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804] `debian-11-generic-amd64-20221108-1193.qcow2` guests w/ Arch Linux host - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18] v1.25.4 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.2.3] 0.5.6 **`Kube-vip.yaml`:** I have it here: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml **Additional context** Add any other context about the problem here. I'm continuing to debug, but wanted to raise an issue with my findings. This is a great project and I'd love to have it support `LoadBalancer` inside a libvirt network 😃

comment.body: This looks like it is something to do with libvirt or the linux bridge ignoring the ARP updates. (this is tunable).. but gratouitous ARP should imediately inform the network of network changes)

issue.title: Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes on the fresh installation of k3s 3-node cluster running on RPi 4b.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install k3s with three master nodes:

```
NAME   STATUS   ROLES                       AGE    VERSION        INTERNAL-IP    EXTERNAL-IP   OS-IMAGE                         KERNEL-VERSION   CONTAINER-RUNTIME
rpi1   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   128m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.41   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
rpi2   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   125m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.42   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
rpi3   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   123m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.43   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
```

2. Deploy kube-vip:

```
curl -s https://kube-vip.io/manifests/rbac.yaml | sudo tee /var/lib/rancher/k3s/server/manifests/kube-vip-rbac.yaml
sudo /usr/local/bin/k3s crictl pull docker.io/plndr/kube-vip:latest
sudo /usr/local/bin/k3s ctr run --rm --net-host docker.io/plndr/kube-vip:latest \
        vip /kube-vip manifest daemonset \
          --arp \
          --interface eth0 \
          --address 192.168.1.30 \
          --controlplane \
          --services \
          --leaderElection \
          --inCluster \
          --taint \
  | sudo tee /var/lib/rancher/k3s/server/manifests/kube-vip.yaml
```

3. Check where the IP is located:

```
arp 192.168.1.30
```
Output of two command executions:
```
? (192.168.1.30) at <mac>:d8 on en0 ifscope [ethernet]
? (192.168.1.30) at <mac>:c9 on en0 ifscope [ethernet]
```

**Expected behavior**
VIP should remain on one node until the node has an issue or is restarted.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: DietPi v8.11.2, kernel 5.15.76-v8+, based on Debian 11 (bullseye)
 - Kubernetes Version: k3s v1.25.3+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: v0.5.7

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.7
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.7
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth0
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: cp_namespace
          value: kube-system
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: address
          value: 192.168.1.30
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.7
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
```

I0921 02:44:15.096571       1 leaderelection.go:283] failed to renew lease kube-system/plndr-cp-lock: timed out waiting for the condition

release.name: v0.5.7
release.body:
Mainly a tidying release:
- fixes slow deletion of kube-vip pod
- Adds comments to all iptables rules created by kube-vip
- Egress tidy will ensure that all rules are cleaned and then re-applied by kube-vip on startup
- Fixes to goroutines etc.

## What's Changed
* Tidies the annotations by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/483
* Adds an annotation for flushing conntrack rules by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/484
* added testing by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/485
* linter: Clean up some linter errors by @stevesloka in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/487
* Fix CVE by @lubronzhan in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489
* garbage collection for goroutines by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/490

## New Contributors
* @lubronzhan made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/compare/v0.5.6...v0.5.7

pull_request.title: garbage collection for goroutines
pull_request.body:
Signed-off-by: Dan Finneran <daniel.finneran@gmail.com>

This adds the following:
- A separate shutdown channel that when closed will ensure all goroutines that hold various contexts or retrywatcher shutdowns is triggered.
- Fixes an issue with slow shutdowns when kubernetes deletes a pod.

issue.title: Dual Stack IPv4/IPv6 Configuration
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
If the address used in the YAML as the VIP address is a dual stack address (k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net as an example) then the outcome is random.  What is the proper method to setup kube-vip as a VIP listener for both stacks?  I have tried the documentation, but it seems a bit vague on the matter.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Use the setup command:
sudo docker run --network host --rm plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8 manifest pod \
--interface ens192 \
--address k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net \
--namespace kube-vip6 \
--arp \
--leaderElection | sudo tee /etc/kubernetes/manifests/vip.yaml

Which produces the correct output.  The resulting configuration seems to cause the VIP to respond on IPv6 only.

**Expected behavior**
VIP would respond on both IPv4 and IPv6


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Fedora Core 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.21.5
 - Kube-vip Version: v0.3.9

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: ens192
    - name: vip_leaderelection
       value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "5"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "3"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "1"
    - name: address
      value: k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net
    image: plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8
    imagePullPolicy: Always
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
       name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
status: {}

issue.title: Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
Looks like the hostname is not replaced in the later version when getting new client from config

- old code replaces hostname in all cases: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.3.6/pkg/cluster/clusterLeader.go#L52-L72
- new code replaces hostname only if `path` is empty: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.4.4/pkg/cluster/clusterLeaderElection.go#L44-L57

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `kube-vip start` with `vip_arp` set to `true`
2. Upgrade from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4


**Expected behavior**
leader election works after upgrade

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18]
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.4

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
  annotations:
    seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/pod: runtime/default
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: eth0
    - name: vip_address
      value: ${LOAD_BALANCER_VIP}
    - name: vip_leaderelection
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "15"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "10"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "2"
    image: repo/kube-vip:0.3.4
    imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  priorityClassName: system-node-critical
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Can't use WLAN interface as vip_interface
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I am trying to use the WiFi interface on my laptop as the vip_interface.  I am using this with DHCP to acquire a dynamic address for the VIP. It fails because it can't find the interface. I am using this for my local test setup.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. kubectl apply -f kube-vip.yml
2. kubectl expose deployment hello-eks-a --port=80 --type=LoadBalancer --name=hello-eks-service --load-balancer-ip=0.0.0.0
3. Check the pod logs and you will see an error "not a valid interface"

**Expected behavior**
Should be able to use the WiFi interface 

**Screenshots**
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=info msg="Service [hello-eks-service] has been addded/modified, it has an assigned external addresses [0.0.0.0]"
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=error msg="Error finding VIP Interface, for building DHCP Link : Link not found"

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 2104]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.22]
 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.3.5]

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        name: kube-vip-ds
    spec:
      hostNetwork: true
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: "**wlp164s0**"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_startleader
          value: "false"
        - name: vip_addpeerstolb
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_localpeer
          value: bfd96b9fcdc3:172.17.0.2:10000
        - name: vip_loglevel
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_address
        image: plndr/kube-vip:0.3.5
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
            - SYS_TIME
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
**Additional context**
The only interface that works is "eth0" but DHCP fails later on because this is not a valid interface on my host. It makes me believe that hostNetwork:true is not taking effect i.e it is not able to see host interfaces.

issue.title: kubevip advertise Loadbalancer IP from all nodes when externalTrafficPolicy: Local configured
issue.body:
I have 4 nodes cluster, 3 master + 1 worker node, I deployed kubevip static pod on 3 master nodes and daemonset on worker node, here is manifest for worker node.

10.196.24.110   vpe-k8s
10.196.24.111   vpe-k8s-master01
10.196.24.112   vpe-k8s-master02
10.196.24.113   vpe-k8s-master03
10.196.24.114   vpe-k8s-worker01
10.196.23.120  TOR switch


```
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  annotations:
    rbac.authorization.kubernetes.io/autoupdate: "true"
  name: system:kube-vip-role
rules:
  - apiGroups: [""]
    resources: ["services"]
    verbs: ["list","get","watch", "update"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: system:kube-vip-binding
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: system:kube-vip-role
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app: kube-vip-workers
  name: kube-vip-workers
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: kube-vip-workers
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app: kube-vip-workers
    spec:
      imagePullSecrets:
      - name: kewangequinix-docker
      containers:
      - image: plndr/kube-vip:0.3.1
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: kube-vip
        command:
        - /kube-vip
        - service
        env:
          - name: vip_interface
            value: "lo"
          - name: bgp_enable
            value: "true"
          - name: vip_loglevel
            value: "5"
          - name: bgp_routerinterface
            value: "ens192"
          - name: bgp_as
            value: "65001"
          - name: bgp_peeraddress
            value: "10.196.24.120"
          - name: bgp_peeras
            value: "65000"
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
```
Then I deploy a nginx service with externalTrafficPolicy: Local and pod is running on worker01 node.

```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx-svc
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  ports:
  - port: 80
    name: web
  selector:
    app: nginx
  type: LoadBalancer
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: web
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  replicas: 1
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      imagePullSecrets:
      - name: kdocker-secret
      containers:
      - name: nginx
        image: nginx
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          name: web
```

With externalTrafficPolicy: Local, I expect loadbalancer IP only advertise by worker01 node, because 3 master nodes are not able to handle the traffic because of externalTrafficPolicy: Local, however, I saw loadbalancer route is learned on TOR switch via 4 nodes, 3 master + 1 worker node, and curl failed sometimes if traffic is sent to master nodes.
```
 B E      192.168.0.201/32 [200/0] via 10.196.24.111, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.112, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.113, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.114, Management1
```
This is unexpected, and I tried with metallb, metallb only advertise BGP from POD running node(in this case is worker01) when externalTrafficPolicy: Local configured.

issue.title: Control Plane HA not clear
issue.body:
Hi and thank you for putting in the work so that we can play with k8s locally.
One thing i don't quite understand or it's a bit unclear , regarding control plane ha ... can't you just use a service of type LoadBalancer instead of having all that configuration ? What would be the issue ?
For example on a default microk8s install there's a service like
```└─$ ▶ kubectl describe svc kubernetes 
Name:              kubernetes
Namespace:         default
Labels:            component=apiserver
                   provider=kubernetes
Annotations:       <none>
Selector:          <none>
Type:              ClusterIP
IP Family Policy:  SingleStack
IP Families:       IPv4
IP:                10.152.183.1
IPs:               10.152.183.1
Port:              https  443/TCP
TargetPort:        16443/TCP
Endpoints:         192.168.100.109:16443
Session Affinity:  None
Events:            <none>
```

Say i have 3 nodes (so a HA setup) , could i just set the service to be type LoadBalancer and achieve the same thing as you would with kube-vip control plane ha ?

Thank you!

issue.title: Log flooded with "\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I just deployed `kube-vip` as a deamonset using this command

```
export INTERFACE=lo

kube-vip manifest daemonset \        
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --inCluster \
    --taint \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection > daemonset.yaml
```

I aslo added the load-balancing environment variable.
```
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
```

HA control plane is working correctly, and I can interact with the AP I server using the VIP.

However, leader pod's log is flooded with this warning/error message

```
 time="2022-10-04T06:04:38Z" level=warning msg="\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
...

issue.title: Dual-Stack VIP
issue.body:
I am trying to setup kube-vip as dual-stack.  I've attempted to run a second instance of Kube-vip by duplicating the yaml and adjusting all of the names to kube-vip6-ds and setting the address to an IPv6 address.  The containers will not start due to this error in the pods.
`msg="listen:listen tcp :2112: bind: address already in use\n"
`
I see the port in use as `*:2112` which indicates to me that the process binds on v4 for some internal communications.  Would it be possible to have that process listen on a tcp6 socket when it detects an IPv6 address?  

Alternatively, simply allow there to be both a v4 and v6 address assigned at the same time.

issue.title: Dual-Stack VIP

I see the port in use as `*:2112` which indicates to me that the process binds on v4 for some internal communications.  Would it be possible to have that process listen on a tcp6 socket when it detects an IPv6 address?  

Alternatively, simply allow there to be both a v4 and v6 address assigned at the same time.

issue.title: [Feature] Support default VIP interface.

milestone.description: Loady-McLoadface release... this brings back the loadbalancer for the API server, amongst a load of other things.

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] -->
Kube-vip is generally deployed as a daemonset in the Kubernetes that means all of the pods in different nodes have the same configuration and all the nodes should have the same network interface. That is a big limitation.

Kube-vip should support the default VIP interface got from the default route on the machine.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
<!--A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.-->
Support the default VIP interface got from the default route on the machine

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
<!--A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.-->

**Additional context**
<!--Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.-->

issue.title: vip_loglevel broken in 0.4.0
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Setting the `vip_loglevel` does not work in 0.4.0. I am setting `vip_loglevel` to `"5"`. Using the same manifest, 0.3.9 shows DEBUG messages while 0.4.0 does not 

**To Reproduce**
Using the following manifest correctly shows DEBUG messages
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - manager
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "false"
    - name: port
      value: "6443"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: lo
    - name: vip_cidr
      value: "32"
    - name: cp_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: cp_namespace
      value: kube-system
    - name: vip_ddns
      value: "false"
    - name: svc_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: bgp_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: bgp_routerid
      value: 192.168.2.1
    - name: bgp_as
      value: "64500"
    - name: bgp_peeraddress
      value: 192.168.2.1
    - name: bgp_peerpass
    - name: bgp_peeras
      value: "64501"
    - name: vip_address
      value: 192.168.2.30
    image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.3.9
    imagePullPolicy: Always
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - NET_RAW
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  hostNetwork: true
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
status: {}
```

Updating the above to use `image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.4.0` no longer produces debug messages. 

Version 0.4.1 also doesn't seem to show DEBUG messages either, but running into other issues with that not accepting `lo` as interface (in BGP mode)

**Expected behavior**
DEBUG log messages shown when setting level to `5`

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Debian 11
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.22.4
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
Provided above

**Additional context**
Trying to debug a BGP issue with Unifi USG and was unable to get DEBUG messages using 0.4.0. During some testing, noticed that rolling back to 0.3.9 started showing DEBUG messages.

issue.title: Image not found
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I followed all the steps in the installation guide for Installation of KubeVIP as a Static Pod (ARP) with containerd. Installation with Docker works as expected, but with containerd it doesn't. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. export VIP=192.168.178.222
2. export INTERFACE=eth0 
3. KVVERSION=$(curl -sL https://api.github.com/repos/kube-vip/kube-vip/releases | jq -r ".[0].name")
4. alias kube-vip="ctr run --rm --net-host ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERSION vip /kube-vip"
5. kube-vip manifest pod \
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection | tee /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-vip.yaml

The following error occurs: 
ctr: image "ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0": not found

Running the same steps with but with <alias kube-vip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERSION"> works fine. 

As I am trying to avoid docker, I would try do let it work directly with containerd. 

**Expected behavior**
Installation of kube-vip

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: CentOS Linux release 7.9.2009 (AltArch)
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.24.3
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**Additional context**
Running on RPI4 directly connected to Network and to the web.

issue.title: container version 0.5.6 does not start due to "iptables not in path"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When generating a pod manifest for the 0.5.6 release, the subsequent pods Crashloops with an error:
```
root@cpu3-blue:~# docker logs a0f447138f6c

time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="Starting kube-vip.io [v0.5.6]"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="namespace [kube-system], Mode: [ARP], Features(s): Control Plane:[true], Services:[true]"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="prometheus HTTP server started"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="Starting Kube-vip Manager with the ARP engine"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=fatal msg="starting new Manager error -> error Creating iptables client [exec: \"iptables\": executable file not found in $PATH]"
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Create kub-vip.yaml with:
```
KKVERS=0.5.5
kubevip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERS"
VIP="is.my.ip.num"
IFACE="iface3"
${kubevip} manifest pod \
    --interface ${IFACE} \
    --address $VIP \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection | tee kube-vip-pods_v0.5.5.yaml
```

And you get a kube-vip pod running correctly. 
```
k get po -n kube-system | grep vip
kube-vip-cpu3-blue                         1/1     Running   0             8m28s
kube-vip-cpu4-blue                         1/1     Running   0             6m1s
kube-vip-cpu5-blue                         1/1     Running   0             5m12s
```
If you change to 0.5.6:
```
KKVERS=0.5.6
kubevip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERS"
VIP="is.my.ip.num"
IFACE="iface3"
${kubevip} manifest pod \
    --interface ${IFACE} \
    --address $VIP \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection | tee kube-vip-pods_v0.5.6.yaml
```

The diff is:
```
# diff kube-vip-pods_v0.5.5.yaml  kube-vip-pods_v0.5.6.yaml
40c40
<     image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.5
---
>     image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.6
```

You get repeated crashloops or errors:
```
$ k get po -n kube-system | grep vip
kube-vip-cpu3-blue                         0/1     Error     2 (26s ago)   28s
```

**Expected behavior**
When you drop a kube-vip.yaml Pod manifest in /etc/kubernetes/manifests with a svc and control-plane loadbalancing, one expects it to be listed in a `kubectl get pod -n kube-system` as `Running`.


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Debian Bullseye
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.23.11
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.5 versus 0.5.6
 - Docker: 20.10.20

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**

The only diff between the borked and the not borked is stated above. If you really want both of them, I can supply.

issue.title: LoadBalancer Service takes > 1 minute to respond in libvirt NAT-networked K8S cluster when called from host
issue.body:
**Describe the bug** I have Kubernetes v1.25.4 running inside libvirt, deployed through `kubeadm`. I have kube-vip configured for both load balancing the API and `Service` `type: LoadBalancer` through ARP. The K8S API works great from my host machine and I have no issue there; however, when I deploy nginx and a `LoadBalancer` service, it takes upwards of 60 seconds for `curl` to come back. I can ping the IP and `arping` comes back with the expected VM mac address. If I `curl` the VIP address from the system it's locally bound to, it still takes about 2 seconds to come back. **To Reproduce** This is the playbook I'm building, which includes all the steps I'm taking to get in this state: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab Manual version of steps: 1. Make a NAT libvirt network with DHCP enabled on a portion of the selected subnet. 2. Bring up VMs on that network (3 control-planes, 3 workers preferably), copy over [this](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml) static pod definition to the control-plane nodes, then initialize the cluster 3. Install flannel with all the defaults 4. [Apply](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/main/roles/kubeadm/tasks/main.yml#L100-L106) the kube-vip-cloud-controller and give it a pool of non-DHCP addresses in that same subnet to use. 5. Deploy an [nginx](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/examples/nginx.yaml) `Deployment` and `Service` 6. Get the LB IP from Kubernetes (in my case, `192.168.123.10`) and curl it on port 8080. ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10:8080 Welcome to nginx!

Welcome to nginx!

If you see this page, the nginx web server is successfully installed and working. Further configuration is required.

For online documentation and support please refer to nginx.org.
Commercial support is available at nginx.com.

Thank you for using nginx.

curl 192.168.123.10:8080 0.00s user 0.00s system 0% cpu 1:04.85 total ``` Real time for the curl to come back is about 1m5s. If I try on a different port (80) which has no service bound on that port, it returns an error instantly: ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10 curl: (7) Failed to connect to 192.168.123.10 port 80 after 0 ms: Couldn't connect to server curl 192.168.123.10 0.00s user 0.00s system 92% cpu 0.005 total ``` **Expected behavior** Data would be returned within a second on a local VM based K8S cluster when curling from the host , and < 2 seconds when curling from the VM which owns the VIP. **Screenshots** Here's a packet capture from the host on the `virbr` network. This is from when I was testing on port 80. The SYN is sent and retransmitted until a minute later we get a SYN ACK from the VIP: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1342149/204119969-ed891414-8dcb-497a-8cbe-1e89a5b8d6a8.png) **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804] `debian-11-generic-amd64-20221108-1193.qcow2` guests w/ Arch Linux host - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18] v1.25.4 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.2.3] 0.5.6 **`Kube-vip.yaml`:** I have it here: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml **Additional context** Add any other context about the problem here. I'm continuing to debug, but wanted to raise an issue with my findings. This is a great project and I'd love to have it support `LoadBalancer` inside a libvirt network 😃

comment.body: This looks like it is something to do with libvirt or the linux bridge ignoring the ARP updates. (this is tunable).. but gratouitous ARP should imediately inform the network of network changes)

issue.title: Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes on the fresh installation of k3s 3-node cluster running on RPi 4b.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install k3s with three master nodes:

```
NAME   STATUS   ROLES                       AGE    VERSION        INTERNAL-IP    EXTERNAL-IP   OS-IMAGE                         KERNEL-VERSION   CONTAINER-RUNTIME
rpi1   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   128m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.41   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
rpi2   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   125m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.42   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
rpi3   Ready    control-plane,etcd,master   123m   v1.25.4+k3s1   192.168.1.43   <none>        Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)   5.15.76-v8+      containerd://1.6.8-k3s1
```

2. Deploy kube-vip:

```
curl -s https://kube-vip.io/manifests/rbac.yaml | sudo tee /var/lib/rancher/k3s/server/manifests/kube-vip-rbac.yaml
sudo /usr/local/bin/k3s crictl pull docker.io/plndr/kube-vip:latest
sudo /usr/local/bin/k3s ctr run --rm --net-host docker.io/plndr/kube-vip:latest \
        vip /kube-vip manifest daemonset \
          --arp \
          --interface eth0 \
          --address 192.168.1.30 \
          --controlplane \
          --services \
          --leaderElection \
          --inCluster \
          --taint \
  | sudo tee /var/lib/rancher/k3s/server/manifests/kube-vip.yaml
```

3. Check where the IP is located:

```
arp 192.168.1.30
```
Output of two command executions:
```
? (192.168.1.30) at <mac>:d8 on en0 ifscope [ethernet]
? (192.168.1.30) at <mac>:c9 on en0 ifscope [ethernet]
```

**Expected behavior**
VIP should remain on one node until the node has an issue or is restarted.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: DietPi v8.11.2, kernel 5.15.76-v8+, based on Debian 11 (bullseye)
 - Kubernetes Version: k3s v1.25.3+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: v0.5.7

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.7
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.7
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth0
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: cp_namespace
          value: kube-system
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: address
          value: 192.168.1.30
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.7
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
```

release.name: v0.5.7
release.body:
Mainly a tidying release:
- fixes slow deletion of kube-vip pod
- Adds comments to all iptables rules created by kube-vip
- Egress tidy will ensure that all rules are cleaned and then re-applied by kube-vip on startup
- Fixes to goroutines etc.

## What's Changed
* Tidies the annotations by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/483
* Adds an annotation for flushing conntrack rules by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/484
* added testing by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/485
* linter: Clean up some linter errors by @stevesloka in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/487
* Fix CVE by @lubronzhan in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489
* garbage collection for goroutines by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/490

## New Contributors
* @lubronzhan made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/compare/v0.5.6...v0.5.7

pull_request.body:
Signed-off-by: Dan Finneran <daniel.finneran@gmail.com>

This adds the following:
- A separate shutdown channel that when closed will ensure all goroutines that hold various contexts or retrywatcher shutdowns is triggered.
- Fixes an issue with slow shutdowns when kubernetes deletes a pod.

issue.title: Dual Stack IPv4/IPv6 Configuration
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
If the address used in the YAML as the VIP address is a dual stack address (k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net as an example) then the outcome is random.  What is the proper method to setup kube-vip as a VIP listener for both stacks?  I have tried the documentation, but it seems a bit vague on the matter.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Use the setup command:
sudo docker run --network host --rm plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8 manifest pod \
--interface ens192 \
--address k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net \
--namespace kube-vip6 \
--arp \
--leaderElection | sudo tee /etc/kubernetes/manifests/vip.yaml

Which produces the correct output.  The resulting configuration seems to cause the VIP to respond on IPv6 only.

**Expected behavior**
VIP would respond on both IPv4 and IPv6


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Fedora Core 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.21.5
 - Kube-vip Version: v0.3.9

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: ens192
    - name: vip_leaderelection
       value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "5"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "3"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "1"
    - name: address
      value: k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net
    image: plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8
    imagePullPolicy: Always
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
       name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
status: {}

issue.title: Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
Looks like the hostname is not replaced in the later version when getting new client from config

- old code replaces hostname in all cases: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.3.6/pkg/cluster/clusterLeader.go#L52-L72
- new code replaces hostname only if `path` is empty: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.4.4/pkg/cluster/clusterLeaderElection.go#L44-L57

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `kube-vip start` with `vip_arp` set to `true`
2. Upgrade from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4


**Expected behavior**
leader election works after upgrade

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18]
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.4

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
  annotations:
    seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/pod: runtime/default
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: eth0
    - name: vip_address
      value: ${LOAD_BALANCER_VIP}
    - name: vip_leaderelection
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "15"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "10"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "2"
    image: repo/kube-vip:0.3.4
    imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  priorityClassName: system-node-critical
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
Looks like the hostname is not replaced in the later version when getting new client from config

- old code replaces hostname in all cases: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.3.6/pkg/cluster/clusterLeader.go#L52-L72
- new code replaces hostname only if `path` is empty: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.4.4/pkg/cluster/clusterLeaderElection.go#L44-L57

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `kube-vip start` with `vip_arp` set to `true`
2. Upgrade from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4


**Expected behavior**
leader election works after upgrade

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18]
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.4

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
  annotations:
    seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/pod: runtime/default
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: eth0
    - name: vip_address
      value: ${LOAD_BALANCER_VIP}
    - name: vip_leaderelection
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "15"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "10"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "2"
    image: repo/kube-vip:0.3.4
    imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  priorityClassName: system-node-critical
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Can't use WLAN interface as vip_interface
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I am trying to use the WiFi interface on my laptop as the vip_interface.  I am using this with DHCP to acquire a dynamic address for the VIP. It fails because it can't find the interface. I am using this for my local test setup.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. kubectl apply -f kube-vip.yml
2. kubectl expose deployment hello-eks-a --port=80 --type=LoadBalancer --name=hello-eks-service --load-balancer-ip=0.0.0.0
3. Check the pod logs and you will see an error "not a valid interface"

**Expected behavior**
Should be able to use the WiFi interface 

**Screenshots**
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=info msg="Service [hello-eks-service] has been addded/modified, it has an assigned external addresses [0.0.0.0]"
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=error msg="Error finding VIP Interface, for building DHCP Link : Link not found"

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 2104]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.22]
 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.3.5]

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        name: kube-vip-ds
    spec:
      hostNetwork: true
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: "**wlp164s0**"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_startleader
          value: "false"
        - name: vip_addpeerstolb
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_localpeer
          value: bfd96b9fcdc3:172.17.0.2:10000
        - name: vip_loglevel
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_address
        image: plndr/kube-vip:0.3.5
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
            - SYS_TIME
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
**Additional context**
The only interface that works is "eth0" but DHCP fails later on because this is not a valid interface on my host. It makes me believe that hostNetwork:true is not taking effect i.e it is not able to see host interfaces.

issue.title: kubevip advertise Loadbalancer IP from all nodes when externalTrafficPolicy: Local configured
issue.body:
I have 4 nodes cluster, 3 master + 1 worker node, I deployed kubevip static pod on 3 master nodes and daemonset on worker node, here is manifest for worker node.

10.196.24.110   vpe-k8s
10.196.24.111   vpe-k8s-master01
10.196.24.112   vpe-k8s-master02
10.196.24.113   vpe-k8s-master03
10.196.24.114   vpe-k8s-worker01
10.196.23.120  TOR switch


```
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  annotations:
    rbac.authorization.kubernetes.io/autoupdate: "true"
  name: system:kube-vip-role
rules:
  - apiGroups: [""]
    resources: ["services"]
    verbs: ["list","get","watch", "update"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: system:kube-vip-binding
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: system:kube-vip-role
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app: kube-vip-workers
  name: kube-vip-workers
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: kube-vip-workers
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app: kube-vip-workers
    spec:
      imagePullSecrets:
      - name: kewangequinix-docker
      containers:
      - image: plndr/kube-vip:0.3.1
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: kube-vip
        command:
        - /kube-vip
        - service
        env:
          - name: vip_interface
            value: "lo"
          - name: bgp_enable
            value: "true"
          - name: vip_loglevel
            value: "5"
          - name: bgp_routerinterface
            value: "ens192"
          - name: bgp_as
            value: "65001"
          - name: bgp_peeraddress
            value: "10.196.24.120"
          - name: bgp_peeras
            value: "65000"
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
```
Then I deploy a nginx service with externalTrafficPolicy: Local and pod is running on worker01 node.

```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx-svc
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  ports:
  - port: 80
    name: web
  selector:
    app: nginx
  type: LoadBalancer
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: web
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  replicas: 1
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      imagePullSecrets:
      - name: kdocker-secret
      containers:
      - name: nginx
        image: nginx
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          name: web
```

With externalTrafficPolicy: Local, I expect loadbalancer IP only advertise by worker01 node, because 3 master nodes are not able to handle the traffic because of externalTrafficPolicy: Local, however, I saw loadbalancer route is learned on TOR switch via 4 nodes, 3 master + 1 worker node, and curl failed sometimes if traffic is sent to master nodes.
```
 B E      192.168.0.201/32 [200/0] via 10.196.24.111, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.112, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.113, Management1
                                   via 10.196.24.114, Management1
```
This is unexpected, and I tried with metallb, metallb only advertise BGP from POD running node(in this case is worker01) when externalTrafficPolicy: Local configured.

issue.title: Control Plane HA not clear
issue.body:
Hi and thank you for putting in the work so that we can play with k8s locally.
One thing i don't quite understand or it's a bit unclear , regarding control plane ha ... can't you just use a service of type LoadBalancer instead of having all that configuration ? What would be the issue ?
For example on a default microk8s install there's a service like
```└─$ ▶ kubectl describe svc kubernetes 
Name:              kubernetes
Namespace:         default
Labels:            component=apiserver
                   provider=kubernetes
Annotations:       <none>
Selector:          <none>
Type:              ClusterIP
IP Family Policy:  SingleStack
IP Families:       IPv4
IP:                10.152.183.1
IPs:               10.152.183.1
Port:              https  443/TCP
TargetPort:        16443/TCP
Endpoints:         192.168.100.109:16443
Session Affinity:  None
Events:            <none>
```

Say i have 3 nodes (so a HA setup) , could i just set the service to be type LoadBalancer and achieve the same thing as you would with kube-vip control plane ha ?

Thank you!

issue.title: Log flooded with "\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I just deployed `kube-vip` as a deamonset using this command

```
export INTERFACE=lo

kube-vip manifest daemonset \        
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --inCluster \
    --taint \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection > daemonset.yaml
```

I aslo added the load-balancing environment variable.
```
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
```

HA control plane is working correctly, and I can interact with the AP I server using the VIP.

However, leader pod's log is flooded with this warning/error message

```
 time="2022-10-04T06:04:38Z" level=warning msg="\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
...

```



**Expected behavior**
Log is not flooded

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.24.4+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

```

kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system

    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds

        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0

          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp

issue.title: Dual-Stack VIP
issue.body:
I am trying to setup kube-vip as dual-stack.  I've attempted to run a second instance of Kube-vip by duplicating the yaml and adjusting all of the names to kube-vip6-ds and setting the address to an IPv6 address.  The containers will not start due to this error in the pods.
`msg="listen:listen tcp :2112: bind: address already in use\n"
`
I see the port in use as `*:2112` which indicates to me that the process binds on v4 for some internal communications.  Would it be possible to have that process listen on a tcp6 socket when it detects an IPv6 address?  

Alternatively, simply allow there to be both a v4 and v6 address assigned at the same time.

issue.title: Dual-Stack VIP

Alternatively, simply allow there to be both a v4 and v6 address assigned at the same time.

issue.title: [Feature] Support default VIP interface.

milestone.description: Loady-McLoadface release... this brings back the loadbalancer for the API server, amongst a load of other things.

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] -->
Kube-vip is generally deployed as a daemonset in the Kubernetes that means all of the pods in different nodes have the same configuration and all the nodes should have the same network interface. That is a big limitation.

Kube-vip should support the default VIP interface got from the default route on the machine.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
<!--A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.-->
Support the default VIP interface got from the default route on the machine

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
<!--A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.-->

**Additional context**
<!--Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.-->

issue.title: vip_loglevel broken in 0.4.0
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Setting the `vip_loglevel` does not work in 0.4.0. I am setting `vip_loglevel` to `"5"`. Using the same manifest, 0.3.9 shows DEBUG messages while 0.4.0 does not 

**To Reproduce**
Using the following manifest correctly shows DEBUG messages
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - manager
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "false"
    - name: port
      value: "6443"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: lo
    - name: vip_cidr
      value: "32"
    - name: cp_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: cp_namespace
      value: kube-system
    - name: vip_ddns
      value: "false"
    - name: svc_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: bgp_enable
      value: "true"
    - name: bgp_routerid
      value: 192.168.2.1
    - name: bgp_as
      value: "64500"
    - name: bgp_peeraddress
      value: 192.168.2.1
    - name: bgp_peerpass
    - name: bgp_peeras
      value: "64501"
    - name: vip_address
      value: 192.168.2.30
    image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.3.9
    imagePullPolicy: Always
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - NET_RAW
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  hostNetwork: true
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
status: {}
```

Updating the above to use `image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.4.0` no longer produces debug messages. 

Version 0.4.1 also doesn't seem to show DEBUG messages either, but running into other issues with that not accepting `lo` as interface (in BGP mode)

**Expected behavior**
DEBUG log messages shown when setting level to `5`

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Debian 11
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.22.4
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
Provided above

**Additional context**
Trying to debug a BGP issue with Unifi USG and was unable to get DEBUG messages using 0.4.0. During some testing, noticed that rolling back to 0.3.9 started showing DEBUG messages.

issue.title: vip_cidr ignored, always 32
issue.body:
kube-vip v0.4.0

```yaml
containers:
        - name: kube-vip
          image: 'ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.4.0'
          args:
            - manager
          env:
            - name: vip_arp
              value: 'true'
            - name: port
              value: '6443'
            - name: vip_interface
              value: enp35s0.4000
            - name: vip_cidr
              value: '29'
            - name: svc_enable
              value: 'true'
```

```
kubectl describe configmap -n kube-system kubevip
Name:         kubevip
Namespace:    kube-system
Labels:       <none>
Annotations:  <none>

Data
====
range-global:
----
321.321.321.218-321.321.321.222
Events:  <none>
```

```
ip addr show enp35s0.4000
3: enp35s0.4000@enp35s0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1400 qdisc noqueue state UP
    inet 321.321.321.221/32 scope global enp35s0.4000
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

Can anyone tell me what to do to have `/29` assigned?
Thx.

issue.title: Image not found
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I followed all the steps in the installation guide for Installation of KubeVIP as a Static Pod (ARP) with containerd. Installation with Docker works as expected, but with containerd it doesn't. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. export VIP=192.168.178.222
2. export INTERFACE=eth0 
3. KVVERSION=$(curl -sL https://api.github.com/repos/kube-vip/kube-vip/releases | jq -r ".[0].name")
4. alias kube-vip="ctr run --rm --net-host ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERSION vip /kube-vip"
5. kube-vip manifest pod \
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \

Running the same steps with but with <alias kube-vip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERSION"> works fine.

issue.title: container version 0.5.6 does not start due to "iptables not in path"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When generating a pod manifest for the 0.5.6 release, the subsequent pods Crashloops with an error:
```
root@cpu3-blue:~# docker logs a0f447138f6c

time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="Starting kube-vip.io [v0.5.6]"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="namespace [kube-system], Mode: [ARP], Features(s): Control Plane:[true], Services:[true]"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="prometheus HTTP server started"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=info msg="Starting Kube-vip Manager with the ARP engine"
time="2022-11-09T19:36:34Z" level=fatal msg="starting new Manager error -> error Creating iptables client [exec: \"iptables\": executable file not found in $PATH]"
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Create kub-vip.yaml with:
```
KKVERS=0.5.5
kubevip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERS"
VIP="is.my.ip.num"
IFACE="iface3"
${kubevip} manifest pod \
    --interface ${IFACE} \
    --address $VIP \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection | tee kube-vip-pods_v0.5.5.yaml
```

And you get a kube-vip pod running correctly. 
```
k get po -n kube-system | grep vip
kube-vip-cpu3-blue                         1/1     Running   0             8m28s
kube-vip-cpu4-blue                         1/1     Running   0             6m1s
kube-vip-cpu5-blue                         1/1     Running   0             5m12s
```
If you change to 0.5.6:
```
KKVERS=0.5.6
kubevip="docker run --network host --rm ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:$KVVERS"
VIP="is.my.ip.num"
IFACE="iface3"
${kubevip} manifest pod \
    --interface ${IFACE} \
    --address $VIP \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection | tee kube-vip-pods_v0.5.6.yaml
```

The diff is:
```
# diff kube-vip-pods_v0.5.5.yaml  kube-vip-pods_v0.5.6.yaml
40c40
<     image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.5
---
>     image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.6
```

You get repeated crashloops or errors:
```
$ k get po -n kube-system | grep vip
kube-vip-cpu3-blue                         0/1     Error     2 (26s ago)   28s
```

**Expected behavior**
When you drop a kube-vip.yaml Pod manifest in /etc/kubernetes/manifests with a svc and control-plane loadbalancing, one expects it to be listed in a `kubectl get pod -n kube-system` as `Running`.


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Debian Bullseye
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.23.11
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.5 versus 0.5.6
 - Docker: 20.10.20

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**

The only diff between the borked and the not borked is stated above. If you really want both of them, I can supply.

issue.title: LoadBalancer Service takes > 1 minute to respond in libvirt NAT-networked K8S cluster when called from host
issue.body:
**Describe the bug** I have Kubernetes v1.25.4 running inside libvirt, deployed through `kubeadm`. I have kube-vip configured for both load balancing the API and `Service` `type: LoadBalancer` through ARP. The K8S API works great from my host machine and I have no issue there; however, when I deploy nginx and a `LoadBalancer` service, it takes upwards of 60 seconds for `curl` to come back. I can ping the IP and `arping` comes back with the expected VM mac address. If I `curl` the VIP address from the system it's locally bound to, it still takes about 2 seconds to come back. **To Reproduce** This is the playbook I'm building, which includes all the steps I'm taking to get in this state: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab Manual version of steps: 1. Make a NAT libvirt network with DHCP enabled on a portion of the selected subnet. 2. Bring up VMs on that network (3 control-planes, 3 workers preferably), copy over [this](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml) static pod definition to the control-plane nodes, then initialize the cluster 3. Install flannel with all the defaults 4. [Apply](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/main/roles/kubeadm/tasks/main.yml#L100-L106) the kube-vip-cloud-controller and give it a pool of non-DHCP addresses in that same subnet to use. 5. Deploy an [nginx](https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/examples/nginx.yaml) `Deployment` and `Service` 6. Get the LB IP from Kubernetes (in my case, `192.168.123.10`) and curl it on port 8080. ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10:8080 Welcome to nginx!

Welcome to nginx!

If you see this page, the nginx web server is successfully installed and working. Further configuration is required.

For online documentation and support please refer to nginx.org.
Commercial support is available at nginx.com.

Thank you for using nginx.

curl 192.168.123.10:8080 0.00s user 0.00s system 0% cpu 1:04.85 total ``` Real time for the curl to come back is about 1m5s. If I try on a different port (80) which has no service bound on that port, it returns an error instantly: ``` ➜ k8s-lab git:(main) ✗ time curl 192.168.123.10 curl: (7) Failed to connect to 192.168.123.10 port 80 after 0 ms: Couldn't connect to server curl 192.168.123.10 0.00s user 0.00s system 92% cpu 0.005 total ``` **Expected behavior** Data would be returned within a second on a local VM based K8S cluster when curling from the host , and < 2 seconds when curling from the VM which owns the VIP. **Screenshots** Here's a packet capture from the host on the `virbr` network. This is from when I was testing on port 80. The SYN is sent and retransmitted until a minute later we get a SYN ACK from the VIP: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1342149/204119969-ed891414-8dcb-497a-8cbe-1e89a5b8d6a8.png) **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804] `debian-11-generic-amd64-20221108-1193.qcow2` guests w/ Arch Linux host - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18] v1.25.4 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.2.3] 0.5.6 **`Kube-vip.yaml`:** I have it here: https://github.com/jrcichra/k8s-lab/blob/f9d2c0a14c2c653570006ebfe7b6c589c03d00d1/roles/kubeadm/files/kube-vip.yaml **Additional context** Add any other context about the problem here. I'm continuing to debug, but wanted to raise an issue with my findings. This is a great project and I'd love to have it support `LoadBalancer` inside a libvirt network 😃

comment.body: This looks like it is something to do with libvirt or the linux bridge ignoring the ARP updates. (this is tunable).. but gratouitous ARP should imediately inform the network of network changes)

issue.title: Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Virtual IP address bouncing between the nodes on the fresh installation of k3s 3-node cluster running on RPi 4b.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install k3s with three master nodes:

```
NAME   STATUS   ROLES                       AGE    VERSION        INTERNAL-IP    EXTERNAL-IP   OS-IMAGE                         KERNEL-VERSION   CONTAINER-RUNTIME

release.name: v0.5.7
release.body:
Mainly a tidying release:
- fixes slow deletion of kube-vip pod
- Adds comments to all iptables rules created by kube-vip
- Egress tidy will ensure that all rules are cleaned and then re-applied by kube-vip on startup
- Fixes to goroutines etc.

## What's Changed
* Tidies the annotations by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/483
* Adds an annotation for flushing conntrack rules by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/484
* added testing by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/485
* linter: Clean up some linter errors by @stevesloka in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/487
* Fix CVE by @lubronzhan in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489
* garbage collection for goroutines by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/490

## New Contributors
* @lubronzhan made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/489

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/compare/v0.5.6...v0.5.7

pull_request.title: garbage collection for goroutines
pull_request.body:
Signed-off-by: Dan Finneran <daniel.finneran@gmail.com>

This adds the following:
- A separate shutdown channel that when closed will ensure all goroutines that hold various contexts or retrywatcher shutdowns is triggered.
- Fixes an issue with slow shutdowns when kubernetes deletes a pod.

issue.title: Dual Stack IPv4/IPv6 Configuration
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
If the address used in the YAML as the VIP address is a dual stack address (k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net as an example) then the outcome is random.  What is the proper method to setup kube-vip as a VIP listener for both stacks?  I have tried the documentation, but it seems a bit vague on the matter.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Use the setup command:
sudo docker run --network host --rm plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8 manifest pod \
--interface ens192 \
--address k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net \
--namespace kube-vip6 \
--arp \
--leaderElection | sudo tee /etc/kubernetes/manifests/vip.yaml

Which produces the correct output.  The resulting configuration seems to cause the VIP to respond on IPv6 only.

**Expected behavior**
VIP would respond on both IPv4 and IPv6


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Fedora Core 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.21.5
 - Kube-vip Version: v0.3.9

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: ens192
    - name: vip_leaderelection
       value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "5"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "3"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "1"
    - name: address
      value: k8s.breepriv.lothlorien.net
    image: plndr/kube-vip:v0.3.8
    imagePullPolicy: Always
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
       name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
status: {}

issue.title: Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Kube-vip fails to take lease after upgrading from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4
Looks like the hostname is not replaced in the later version when getting new client from config

- old code replaces hostname in all cases: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.3.6/pkg/cluster/clusterLeader.go#L52-L72
- new code replaces hostname only if `path` is empty: https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/blob/v0.4.4/pkg/cluster/clusterLeaderElection.go#L44-L57

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `kube-vip start` with `vip_arp` set to `true`
2. Upgrade from 0.3.6 to 0.4.4


**Expected behavior**
leader election works after upgrade

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 1804]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.18]
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.4.4

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
  annotations:
    seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/pod: runtime/default
spec:
  containers:
  - args:
    - start
    env:
    - name: vip_arp
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_interface
      value: eth0
    - name: vip_address
      value: ${LOAD_BALANCER_VIP}
    - name: vip_leaderelection
      value: "true"
    - name: vip_leaseduration
      value: "15"
    - name: vip_renewdeadline
      value: "10"
    - name: vip_retryperiod
      value: "2"
    image: repo/kube-vip:0.3.4
    imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
    name: kube-vip
    resources: {}
    securityContext:
      capabilities:
        add:
        - NET_ADMIN
        - SYS_TIME
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
      name: kubeconfig
    - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs
      name: ca-certs
      readOnly: true
  hostNetwork: true
  hostAliases:
  - hostnames:
    - kubernetes
    ip: 127.0.0.1
  priorityClassName: system-node-critical
  volumes:
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf
    name: kubeconfig
  - hostPath:
      path: /etc/ssl/certs
    name: ca-certs
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Can't use WLAN interface as vip_interface
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I am trying to use the WiFi interface on my laptop as the vip_interface.  I am using this with DHCP to acquire a dynamic address for the VIP. It fails because it can't find the interface. I am using this for my local test setup.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. kubectl apply -f kube-vip.yml
2. kubectl expose deployment hello-eks-a --port=80 --type=LoadBalancer --name=hello-eks-service --load-balancer-ip=0.0.0.0
3. Check the pod logs and you will see an error "not a valid interface"

**Expected behavior**
Should be able to use the WiFi interface 

**Screenshots**
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=info msg="Service [hello-eks-service] has been addded/modified, it has an assigned external addresses [0.0.0.0]"
time="2022-04-15T17:33:03Z" level=error msg="Error finding VIP Interface, for building DHCP Link : Link not found"

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: [e.g. Ubuntu 2104]
 - Kubernetes Version: [e.g. v.1.22]
 - Kube-vip Version: [e.g. 0.3.5]

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        name: kube-vip-ds
    spec:
      hostNetwork: true
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: "**wlp164s0**"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_startleader
          value: "false"
        - name: vip_addpeerstolb
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_localpeer
          value: bfd96b9fcdc3:172.17.0.2:10000
        - name: vip_loglevel
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_address
        image: plndr/kube-vip:0.3.5
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
            - SYS_TIME
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
**Additional context**
The only interface that works is "eth0" but DHCP fails later on because this is not a valid interface on my host. It makes me believe that hostNetwork:true is not taking effect i.e it is not able to see host interfaces.
